objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe number 19 appears in ink in the top right corner of the object. However, this number (corresponding to the number of the page in volume II of William Upcott's Reliques of My Contemporaries on which Blake's autograph appears) is written in a hand other than Blake’s and is therefore not included in this transcription.
objinfo.binding: bound in dark green morocco The present binding was created in 1833 "by Hering".

provenance.name: New York Public Library
provenance.note: The collection of autographs in which Blake's inscription appears was probably once bound in one book or notebook. Upcott had the collection rebound in two volumes in 1833. These volumes were later aquired by Owen D. Young who, along with Dr. Albert A. Berg, presented them to the New York Public Library on 5 May 1941.

repository.collection: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

objtitle.title: Blake's Autograph in the Album of William Upcott

objnote.p: The number 19, indicating that this object is the nineteenth leaf of the second volume of this particular collection, is written in ink and in a hand other than Blake's at the top right corner of the object.

The top third of the object contains the autographs of various individuals who signed Upcott's original album. These signatures are not replicated here. Blake's signature appears immediately below that of B. R. Haydon.

Lines 1-4, which surround Blake's drawing of a male figure, were first sketched out in pencil before being inked over in order to plot out their position relative to the drawing. These faint pencil lines, still visible in some areas (and traced in red in the sample below), were either imperfectly erased after the lines were rewritten in ink or have simply faded over time.

A number of letters appearing in words from lines 15 to 17 contain additional strokes. See, for example, the "h" in "Autograph" (line 15) and the "d" in "Comfield" (line 16). Blake's pen may have needed mending.

Lines 18-21 are taken from Wordsworth's Poems (1815), which was loaned to Blake by Crabb Robinson in December of 1825 (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 1322n). They appear in one of a series of sonnets that were originally published by Wordsworth in 1807. The first is entitled "From the Italian of Michael Angelo," while all subsequent sonnets in the series (including that cited by Blake) are entitled "From the Same." In Wordsworth's Poems (1815), the lines, which Blake either copied or remembered imperfectly, are as follows: "Heaven-born, the Soul a heaven-ward course must hold; / Beyond the visible world She soars to seek, / (For what delights the sense is false and weak) / Ideal Form, the universal mould" (volume 2, page 179). Blake also refers to this particular sonnet in his annotations to Wordsworth's Poems (1815) (volume 1, page 44).
